thread.title: Hurns lifts Jaguars past Bills in roller-coaster London game
thread.title_full: Hurns lifts Jaguars past Bills in roller-coaster London game

author: Staff
title: Hurns lifts Jaguars past Bills in roller-coaster London game
text:
Hurns lifts Jaguars past Bills in roller-coaster London game 
By Hays Carlyon • hays.carlyon@jacksonville.com Sun, Oct 25, 2015 @ 1:02 pm | updated Sun, Oct 25, 2015 @ 1:05 pm Photos AP/Tim Ireland Jaguars receiver Allen Hurns dives to catch the winning touchdown in Sunday's 34-31 victory over the Bills in London. Videos Read the latest Jaguars coverage 
LONDON -- The Jaguars can finally have a happy trip back across the Atlantic Ocean. 
Quarterback Blake Bortles connected with receiver Allen Hurns on a 31-yard touchdown with 2:16 to play to give the Jaguars a 34-31 victory over Buffalo on Sunday at Wembley Stadium in front of 84,021 fans. 
The Jaguars came back to avoid perhaps a devastating loss. The Bills rallied from 27-3 to take the lead on a 42-yard interception return for a touchdown by safety Corey Graham with 5:21 to play. 
Following Hurns’ touchdown, the Jaguars defense held Buffalo on downs with cornerback Aaron Colvin breaking up a pass. 
The victory send the Jaguars into the bye week at 2-5. 
The Jaguars defense scored two touchdowns in a span of minutes in the second quarter to spark the early lead. 
Defensive end Chris Clemons picked up a fumble by Buffalo quarterback EJ Manuel and returned it six yards for a score. Colvin forced the fumble, sacking Manuel on a blitz. 
On Buffalo’s next possession, outside linebacker Telvin Smith intercepted Manuel and returned it 26 yards for a touchdown, giving the Jaguars a 21-3 lead. 
The Jaguars offense book ended the two defensive scores with touchdowns. 
The Jaguars took a 7-3 lead, answering a Buffalo 31-yard field goal. 
Bortles recognized a Bills blitz and quickly threw a pass to Robinson, who fought a defender enough to get into the end zone for a 10-yard touchdown with 14:05 
Then, the defense took over. 
Running back T.J. Yeldon continued the momentum with a 28-yard touchdown run to push the lead to 27-3. Kicker Jason Myers missed the extra point. 
The four-touchdown quarter was the first for the Jaguars since 2011 and only the second occurrence in the last 15 seasons 
The Jaguars held a 27-13 lead over Buffalo in the third quarter. They had a first down at the Bills 1-yard line. 
Running back Toby Gerhart was stuffed for no gain on four consecutive runs. 
Welcome to the meltdown. 
The Jaguars then allowed the Bills to kick a field goal after starting at their 1. 
Manuel connected with receiver Marcus Easley for a 58-yard touchdown. 
Bortles was intercepted by Graham, who returned it 42 yards for a touchdown. 
Buffalo had taken a 31-27 lead with 5:21 to play after trailing 27-3. 
The Bills (3-4) were without their starting quarterback (Tyrod Taylor), their two best receivers (Sammy Watkins and Percy Harvin) and two starting offensive linemen.
